thread.title: Loss to Houston perfectly reflects Seattle Mariners’ season - Thu, 01 Oct 2015 PST
thread.title_full: Loss to Houston perfectly reflects Seattle Mariners’ season - Thu, 01 Oct 2015 PST

title: Loss to Houston perfectly reflects Seattle Mariners’ season - Thu, 01 Oct 2015 PST
text:
Loss to Houston perfectly reflects Seattle Mariners’ season Bob Dutton Tacoma News Tribune Email 
SEATTLE – On a night when the Mariners, out of necessity, trolled through much of their bullpen, the game turned on a slip-and-slide tumble by right fielder Brad Miller with the game tied in the seventh inning. 
The season should have ended Wednesday for the Mariners in this 7-6 loss to … Associated Press photo Houston’s Luis Valbuena, left, is greeted by Marwin Gonzalez after scoring on a three-run homer by Chris Carter during the sixth inning. (Full-size photo) Hernandez won’t pitch 
 Mariners ace Felix Hernandez is done for the season after manager Lloyd McClendon decided not to have the right-hander pitch on the final weekend. 
 McClendon announced his decision Wednesday before Seattle closed out a series against Houston. 
 McClendon said it wasn’t worth the stress on Hernandez’s arm to have him make one more start against Oakland. Hisashi Iwakuma will start Friday, Roenis Elias on Saturday and Vidal Nuno will pitch the finale Sunday. 
 Hernandez will finish the season with an 18-9 record and 3.53 ERA. 
Associated Press 
SEATTLE – On a night when the Mariners, out of necessity, trolled through much of their bullpen, the game turned on a slip-and-slide tumble by right fielder Brad Miller with the game tied in the seventh inning. 
The season should have ended Wednesday for the Mariners in this 7-6 loss to the Houston Astros at Safeco Field. This was a perfect metaphor for a season that saw spring hopes fade slowly into harsh disappointment. 
It was 6-all with one out in the seventh when Evan Gattis sent a fly to right field. It should either be caught or, maybe, fall for a single. But Miller lost his footing as he charged toward the ball. 
The result was a triple. (Miller overthrew the relay man, but Gattis would likely have reached third in any event.) 
After Jonathan Villar replaced Gattis as a pinch-runner, the Mariners shortened their infield – which meant Colby Rasmus’ soft bloop against Danny Farquhar (1-7) landed beyond a retreating Ketel Marte from short. 
There was more, of course, including a brutal outing by reliever JC Ramirez after he inherited a 6-3 lead in the sixth inning. 
Also, credit the Astros, fighting to reach postseason as part of a remarkable turnaround, for overcoming deficits of 2-0 and 6-3. They lead the Los Angeles Angels by one-half game for the final wild-card berth. 
Tony Sipp (3-4) got the victory when Luke Gregerson pitched a scoreless ninth for his 31st save. 
For the Mariners, this was the seventh loss in eight games in a season that concludes this weekend with three required games against Oakland’s even more disappointing Athletics. 
Let’s reset: 
The M’s had just surrendered a 2-0 lead when Houston scored three runs in the fifth when they muscled up a four-run answer. 
One-out singles by Jesus Sucre and Ketel Marte put runners at first and third before Kyle Seager jumped a high slider from Houston starter Scott Kazmir for a 409-foot homer to right-center field. 
The Mariners led 5-3. 
Nelson Cruz followed with a similar drive to right-center for his 44th homer of the season. 
The Mariners turned to Ramirez with a 6-3 lead in the sixth. 
First, Ramirez failed to handle a bunt by Carlos Gomez, which turned into single. Next, Ramirez ignored Gomez, who stole second without throw. Then came a walk to Luis Valbuena. 
Finally, Ramirez jumped ahead 0-2 on Chris Carter before putting a slider on a tee. Carter drove it 418 feet to left for a game-tying homer. That was it for Ramirez.
